resources.string: Signs of potential cerebral palsy can be detected within the first months of life. Thorough observation of the baby can help detect the symptoms soon enough to treat them. Each "Yes" means you child displays a symptom of CP.

string-array.name: test_newborn_result_bad_paragraphs
string-array.item: Risk of CP found
You should consult a doctor

string-array.name: test_newborn
string-array.item: Does the child seem stiff when lying on the back? Is there any increase muscle tone?
Does your child maintain a fetal position when lying on the back?
Does your child’s arms and back remain bent during bathing or changing diapers?
Does your child keep their arms bent and close to the body when lying on the back?
Does your child resist flexion of the limbs when lying on the back?
Does your child tend to cross their legs in the shin area?
Does the child lie with all limbs unbent? Can the child maintain a frog-like position?
Does your child display decreased spontaneous activity?
When you stretch your child by the arms, does your child tilt their head back without stretching it with the rest of the body?
Does the child actively resist unbending their arms?
Is there a drastic decrease in flexing capability?
Is one arm unbent at a greater angle than the other?
Does the child have difficulty turning their head to the side? Does the child protest against being put in this position?
Does the child keep their limbs unbent when lying on the stomach (frog-like pose)?
When you hold the child in the air face down, are their arms bent? Is their head lowered?
When held vertically, do the child’s arms and legs hang loosely?
Does the child fail to maintain a position?
When put on something vertically, does the child suddenly bend their legs or tilt their head back?
Does the child’s cry sound quiet or weak? Sheer or painful? Are there any single outcries?
Does the child grimace instead of crying?
Does the child lack visual and auditory concentration by the time they reach 1 month?
Does the child lack "mouth attention"? (When a child half-opens their mouth as if trying to respond to the adult’s speech. When spoken to kindly, the child can respond by a brief first smile.)
Does your child frown or seem unhappy?
Does the child hate changing diapers or being examined?
Does the child cry a lot for no good reason? Is the child excessively sleepy?
